summaries.body: The day my Megabus caught fire: There were a series of pops, and before we knew it, the bus was in flames. A Times travel writer's first-time trip on a Megabus goes awry.

display_asset.caption: Donald J. Trump spoke approvingly about bullets dipped in pig’s blood at a rally on Friday in North Charleston, S.C.

summaries.body: The sister of a Muslim student killed in North Carolina challenged Donald J. Trump to meet her after he spoke about killing Islamic terrorists with bullets dipped in pigs' blood.

display_asset.caption: Harper Lee appears in a picture on Opus the penguin’s wall in a 1995 cartoon by Berkeley Breathed.

summaries.body: Despite a reclusive reputation, Harper Lee corresponded with Berkeley Breathed, the man behind the comic strip "Bloom County." He shared the letters with The Times.
Jeff Arnold, a writer, apologized for an article in SB Nation that many saw as sympathetic to Daniel Holtzclaw, a former police officer who was convicted of raping women.

display_asset.caption: Traffic in the Wan Chai area of Hong Kong. Demand for auspicious license plates has pushed prices to new heights.

summaries.body: A license plate was sold in Hong Kong for $2.3 million, the highest price ever paid in the city. It carries the number 28, which in Cantonese sounds like a phrase for “easy money.”

display_asset.caption: The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, led by Wynton Marsalis, will perform 10 concert programs in the Rose Theater during the 2016-17 season.
display_asset.credit: Ian Douglas for The New York Times

summaries.body: Jazz at Lincoln Center has announced its lineup for the 2016-17 season, which will celebrate a clutch of jazz centenaries and welcome an array of familiar collaborators.

display_asset.caption: The HSBC building in Hong Kong. The banking giant is being investigated over the hiring of candidates with ties to government officials in the Asia-Pacific region.

summaries.body: HSBC reported a loss in the fourth quarter as growth in China slowed and warned that it was being investigated over hiring practices in the Asia-Pacific region.

display_asset.credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times

summaries.body: Nearly 40 percent of Baltimore’s police officers are black. But the force’s diversity has not helped it much in gaining approval from the city’s black community.

display_asset.caption: Rosario Ferré at her home in San Juan, P.R., in 1998.

summaries.body: Rosario Ferré, a National Book Award finalist who wrote novels about Puerto Rican identity, has died at 77.

display_asset.caption: Samsung’s new Gear 360, a camera for recording virtual-reality videos.

summaries.body: Samsung will begin selling a virtual reality camera this year called the Gear 360. It has two lenses, allowing users to film 360-degree video.

posts.footer: — Emma Coronel Aispuro, the wife of El Chapo, speaks for the first time publicly about her marriage, and her fears for her imprisoned husband. The Los Angeles Times

summaries.body: I'm afraid for his life.

display_asset.caption: A vacuum gauge on a maple tree. Improvements in technology have contributed to increases in syrup production in recent years.
display_asset.credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times

summaries.body: A mild winter makes for sweeter pancakes, and northern New York's maple-syrup producers may be in for a record-setting season.

display_asset.caption: The letters seem to lean together, evoking the tapering walls of Temple of Dendur.

summaries.body: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s quiet launch of a new logo has been met by noisy opposition, with one designer calling it “in capital letters: ATROCIOUS."

display_asset.caption: Melissa Click, left, in a still frame from the YouTube video that brought her widespread criticism, and in a headshot released recently by a public relations firm.
display_asset.credit: Mark Schierbecker, via Associated Press, left; Status Labs, right

summaries.body: A University of Missouri professor addressed criticism she received after she attempted to stop a student journalist from filming a protest over racial issues.

display_asset.caption: Ethan Couch, 18, in Fort Worth, Tex., this month in a booking photo provided by the Tarrant County Sheriff’s Department.
display_asset.credit: Tarrant County Sheriff's Department, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A judge ordered the case of Ethan Couch, who a witness argued suffered from “affluenza,” to be transferred to an adult court, meaning he faces jail time in four traffic deaths.

display_asset.caption: Beyoncé performing at Super Bowl 50 this month. She and her dancers wore outfits widely perceived to be reminiscent of the Black Panther movement.

summaries.body: The Miami Fraternal Order of Police said it voted to let its members boycott a concert by Beyoncé, citing her Super Bowl halftime performance.

display_asset.caption: An uproar ensued after Larycia Hawkins, a Christian who worked at Wheaton College, posted on Facebook an image of herself in a hijab, with the caption: “I stand in religious solidarity with Muslims because they, like me, a Christian, are people of the book. And as Pope Francis stated last week, we worship the same God.”
display_asset.credit: Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A professor who left her job at a Christian school after saying that Christians and Muslims worship the same god has revived the complicated debate.

display_asset.caption: At Christie’s London on Feb. 11, two telephone bidders pushed Peter Doig’s 1991 painting ‘‘The Architect’s Home in the Ravine’’ to £11.3 million with fees.
display_asset.credit: Peter Doig. All Rights Reserved, DACS 2016, via Christie's Images. 2016

summaries.body: The first big round of art auctions of 2016 suggests a tough year ahead for auction houses amid financial turbulence.

display_asset.caption: Alyssa Leader, a Harvard graduate, is suing the university.

summaries.body: A Harvard graduate has filed a lawsuit accusing the school of failing to protect her from her assailant after she was sexually assaulted.

display_asset.caption: Heavy machinery excavating the Wei-Guan Golden Dragon apartment complex in Tainan, Taiwan. The remains of a homeless woman, the last known victim of the Feb. 6 earthquake, were found on Thursday.

summaries.body: Workers in Taiwan found the body of the last person still listed as missing after the collapse of a 17-story building in an earthquake on Feb. 6, officials said.

display_asset.caption: Kenneth Griffin, the founder of Citadel, a $26 billion investment firm, has developed an appetite for notable art.

summaries.body: The hedge fund founder Kenneth Griffin bought elite art-world status, paying $500 million for Pollock and de Kooning works that he lent to the Art Institute of Chicago.
In a case that pits animal rights against property rights, a Virginia woman is on trial for taking a pit bull chained outside a home after hearing that the dog was being abused.

display_asset.caption: California Occupational Safety and Health Standards Board member Patty Quinlan, right, listens with other members during a meeting regarding proposed regulations for the adult entertainment industry.

summaries.body: California's pornography industry used martial artists and plumbers as evidence to fight a proposal that would force performers to wear condoms and, in some cases, goggles.

display_asset.caption: A wild turkey perched on the hood of a Honda Accord in Hillsdale, N.J., last fall.

summaries.body: Wild turkeys are overrunning parts of New Jersey, and even causing alarm. One 911 call said a carrier was trapped by turkeys that "won't let him deliver the mail."

display_asset.caption: Lady Gaga in a look from Marc Jacobs’s fall/winter 2016 show.

summaries.body: Marc Jacobs turned heads at New York Fashion Week, using Lady Gaga as a runway model for his fall/winter show.

display_asset.caption: A new map shows which ecosystems are most sensitive to changes in certain environmental factors — temperature, water availability and cloud cover. Areas in red are the most sensitive, and green the least sensitive. Gray areas show ice-covered land or deserts.

summaries.body: Scientists are studying the earth at the plant level to see which ecosystems are altered the most by climate change. They found surprising vulnerability in some regions.

display_asset.caption: In a complaint, Bill Cosby said that Andrea Constand, above, broke the terms of a 2006 confidential agreement.
display_asset.credit: Marta Iwanek/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Bill Cosby has sued to seek the return of money he gave in a financial settlement to Andrea Constand, who accused him of drugging and sexually assaulting her in 2004.

display_asset.credit: Channel 7, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

summaries.body: A plant known as “hairy panic” has left parts of a small town in Australia inundated with tumbleweeds, and with global media attention.

display_asset.caption: Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center was attacked by hackers this month.

summaries.body: A Los Angeles hospital paid a ransom of about $17,000 to hackers who had used a malware attack to hold the hospital's computer system hostage.

display_asset.caption: A woman posing for wedding photos on the Shanghai riverfront. The Communist Party’s antigraft commission has issued instructions to officials on avoiding extravagance at weddings and funerals.

summaries.body: Is the guest list too long? That's one of the questions that Communist Party officials in China must ponder when planning weddings or funerals as part of an antigraft effort.
